comments.commentBody:
Sorry, you don't think Romney is in this for power and glory? I may disagree with Gingrich on everything, but he was right that the only reason Romney hasn't been in office for the past 17 years is because he lost to Kennedy in 1994.

Seduction by platitude.

It's probably a love-hate relationship with America to Mr. Romney, to be consistent with his bipolarity on other public issues.

I think Mr. Romney's love for his own family is pure, but that of course is private.

"I love this country"...sincere words from Mitt Romney...spoken more than once by Romney, in tonights debate.

Mr. Romney has it all in his private life. He doesn't have to subject himself into the belly of the beast (politics). If he becomes president, he will go through virtual hell, considering the culture we now live in. It will take a strong man of character and resolve to change Washington...Gov. Romney is now girding himself for the task.

On the Gingrich presidency...he has been there (Washington) he would most likely go with the flow (status quo) the K-Street shadow government would multiply...and government gridlock would go on...Democrats versus Republicans. To believe that Democrats would work with a president Gingrich...is to believe that Republicans will work with President Obama if he is re-elected.

Either way, there will be more divided government.

"I love this country"...Romney said, is the reason he is running for the presidency. To the openminded viewer, it would seem that it is not...power...he is looking for, but a stable nation, that must be restored to what it once was.

I love this country...words not spoken by any other candidate tonight...not even the frontrunner...Newt Gingrich.

Words to contemplate...are there some running just for personal power and glory? Would Gingrich fit that mold...his total adult life, consumed by politics?

Now is the time to talk of many things...skepticism is one.

I would explain it to the parents exactly the way it was explained here.  "Acting weird" may not seem like a lot to go on, but if it were my kid I'd want to know.  It doesn't seem harmful to provide parents with that bit of information, and it could be helpful to them in a larger context that others are unaware of.
great photography and great photojournalism.   Hey photo editor of the nyt -  give this woman a job.

It is sobering and heartbreaking to see people living like this. Every human being deserves a warm, healthy place to live. And one wonders how different their lives might be in less chaotic living quarters.

Makes me think about Ellen Baxter, and her amazing work among the chronically homeless in NYC. The Times has profiled her in the past. We need such visionaries.

I do root strongly against all things Wilpon.  It's odd, I never disliked them before Madoff, but when you look back, they just mess up everything.  From hiring Harazin and the worst team money could buy, to lights up the room, to skill sets, to meaningful games, to the decor of Dodger...oops...that ballpark for daddy with the bogus dimensions.  And then you wonder when the Angels reportedly get 3-billion for t-v rights, maybe they would have been smarter not to pile up debt to create their own network.  As Case would say, "can't anybody here run this team?"

I am writing a comment here because I could not find a place to comment on your article about the origins of violence in hockey.

Several years ago I shared a flight with an NHL scout for the Calgary Flames and I asked him why hockey was so violent and his no hesitation answer was " alcohol, we were drunk for every game " He was a member of the Chicago Blackhawks when there were 7 teams I think. He said they were drunk before, during and after every game and so when someone got checked to hard, a fight broke out and sometimes a fight just broke out. He said it was always a rough game but the protection was not good in the early days and that and the combination of booze was the reason fighting was just part of the game and why it remains today. Seems obvious .

Impressive article! However, I do not believe we could follow the Japanese model. Japanese culture and life style are different from ours. In Japan kids are trained in discipline and respect from early age the way only solders are trained in America. A lot of brilliant teachers in our country waste valuable time on "babysitting some students, instead of teaching.

Thanks for the article.

This article was incredibly insightful and helps shed light on a political party from Egypt we are very ignorant about in the west but when you say "Rather, they vote for Islamic parties for the same reason ... Southerners favor conservative Christians" I could think of nothing more scary of religious extremists putting a threat on the world if current some GOP candidates such as Rick Perry were to win the president election and my mind starts to tremble a little in fear again.

For those involved in and concerned with water purification in areas desperately needing water purification and safety, please go to www.SWIM.com for information. This is an NGO that produces a water purification unit for global supply. It is NON-PROFIT group that supplies these units and training. That is there is no government involvment or any profit motive involved. The cost factor is, only, for the materials involved. Thus, purchase pays for the next unit unit to be produced. Win-win-win....making a difference in the lives of thousands and thousands.

Mr. Kristof, You still do not understand. You need to speek with Coptics, poor people in the streel not young beautiful maiden. Yes, the Brothers know what you like. But try to see what people in the street say. Taxi drivers.Be careful with good looking female interpreters. They will not translate what they do not want you to hear. Lastly, come home! You a a journalistic failure.

Let's go back to November, 2004. I walked into work a few days after the election and saw someone had posted a copy of the front page of London's Daily Mirror, with a large picture of George W. Bush and the words beneath it reading, "How can 59 million people be so dumb?" I'm guessing there were a large number of citizens of the Middle East at that time who were as worried about their future as were many liberal Americans. And yet, we survived.

Every citizen of every democracy has, as your wise 18 year old protege pointed out, the right to be wrong. God knows we exercise that right here in America on a regular basis - so why do we insist on depriving others of that same right?

Oh, yes - I've read the pronouncements from the fear-mongers. They use words like "appeasement" with contempt, as though working for peace and allowing citizens of other nations the right of self-determination should be a topic of debate. Those are the people that give citizens of other nations around the world a reason to hate and fear the US.

I don't want to be hated and feared - any more than the Salafis and the Muslim Brotherhood want to. We are fellow humans on this planet - when will we start acting that way?

Hi,
I am an Iranian girl studying in UK . I am amazed how Egyptians sound familiar and think to myself that Iranian were really advanced to have had this 35 years ago.
I keep warning my Egyptian friend not to end up like us and he keeps reassuring me"' we know what we want''... oh god! how familiar he sounds.
Then later I think to myself that an Islamic regime is what every single Islamic country owe to the history. It takes generations to understand that human flaws have nothing to do with religion neither does religion to do with humanity. Religion is just a mother telling kid what to do and what not to!!
Anyway it's about time for Islam to pay its debt to rulers and to start its Renascence (knowing its been born later than Christianity). I wish all the Arab countries that are in this process best of luck. I wont be upset if I'd be proved wrong.

You write "People don’t vote for Islamic parties because they seek Saudi- or Iranian-style religious repression." They may not seek it, but it may just come as a package deal. Khomeini too, represented traditional values and was adored by the Iranian masses. I wonder how he is judged today by the Iranians.

As one who has championed women's rights in Muslim countries, I would think you would more skeptical of Egypt's radical right's motives. Politicians have been known to say one thing and mean another.

By the way, I don't recall Nasser to have been as benign as you make him out to be. Nor was he any bargain for the Egyptian people.

I was born and raised in Ismailia. I know the type of people you have talked about in your article. I do not want to sound patronizing in saying "don't be easily deceived." These people are the most intolerant people I have ever known...they may serve their coreligionists well, but it stops there! They hate and persecute all people belonging to other religions or beliefs. They have had a well-known violent past...they were the ones to blame for the extremist Islamist radicalization the entire world has been struggling with in recent years. Their services to women will almost always have some hidden motives and/or benefits. Their services to society are to empower them and gain them votes, so that they can take over. Once they are in control, then...watch out!
Unfortunately, a huge number of Egyptians are poor and illiterate, thus they are easily bought with bread and mundane services. The government has failed in providing for its people, and the Islamists knew exactly where the void was...they have been doing this for years while the government was asleep and subduing the discontent by its power and repression...no one cared as long as the status quo remained, the rich getting richer and the poor getting poorer, meanwhile the Islamists taking advantage of the whole mess...and very happy with it too!

If I am to fear the Muslim Brotherhood, as some GOP Candidates and their followers believe, shouldn't I also fear The Knights of Columbus?.

Oh right, they do. They just don't say it since there is a voter demographic in play.

I'm wary, but not necessarily fearful, of all three groups I mentioned.

Oregon is hardly a "satellite" of San Francisco or Berkeley. Stereotyping people and lumping entire states together is narrow-minded and, to use your term, naive. For your information, most of Oregon is rural and red-state as can be. By your logic, because you are from Massachusetts, you must be a liberal socialist who loves the thought of raising taxes. True?

Maybe it is just the NW that brings these wishful thinkers to the media.  One can remember the famous John Reed and "Ten Days the Changed the World".  Oh that Kristoff would be right.  Not many would say he is anything other than another Utopianist.

Kristoff is from the left/west coast, specifically Oregon (sort of a satellite of San Fran and Berkeley), and as we all are creatures of our environment, this truism suggests that Nick is a wellmeaning but naive child.  Here comes this jovial joker from the NYT and asks baby questions to sweet young females in the Moslem Brotherhood and gets pro-democratic pablum as answers!  Doesn't this guy realize that they are rehearsed to make nice to nosey Westerners?  And didn't he ever hear of  taqiya (dissimulation), a wellknown and favorite Moslem method of lying while smiling? I think Kristoff is in line with those other great NYT reporters of the past who waxed eloquent about Fidel in the '60's and Stalin in the '30s...

Let's have a gentleman's bet.  I'll bet that Egypt will become a religious state (either formally, or by action) and that minority religious groups, especially Christians will be persecuted.  I give it less than one year.

The purpose of the Commerce Clause is to ensure the free movement of goods through the various States without restriction. This includes precluding a State from granting sole transportation authority to a State designated carrier.
As to the interstate purchase of health insurance, there are no regulations that prevent National Insurance companies from setting up offices in the individual States. The only requirement is that they comply with State Rules and regulations.

That's not strictly true, Dave. While voting was not extended to women universally until the passage of the 19th Amendment in 1920, the US Constitution was was explicitly gender neutral. The word "men" is never used in the constitution, only the words "Person" and "Persons". The use of masculine pronouns was inherent in the English language at the time.
I hope you are right. Did not watch the 'debate', waiting for some highlights.

"They already know Barack Obama isn’t the messiah he was once cracked up to be. What they don’t know is whether they can trust anyone else to do better."

Neither is Newt, what he himself says/portrays as if he is, as he did in the ABC-Yahoo debate tonight in Iowa. What his supporters think he is or has been is a dilemma for them.

Major establishment Republicans have come out against him.

The guy who was denied a tenure in a little known college in GA is NOT an academic genius I'd be afraid of, particularly with his embarrassing reversals in his political and personal family-value views. I don't know why but Ron Paul is beginning to make more sense to me (and I'm no Ayn Rand libertarian) and more reliable than a man with a history of opportunistic 'serial hypocrisy'. Paul, agree with him or not, has at least been brutally open and consistent. Quite contrast to the intellectually uncertain and morally inconsistent Newt.

I am an independent, who has been somewhat disappointed in Obama, but the Dems can handle Newt any day, and Obama can out-do the so-called 'historian' Newt in any debate (even on FOX).

Prof. Historian has to come to terms with is own personal and political history, and the criticism from a wide variety of establishment conservative Republicans. The Republican primary/caucus voters need to worry about that a little more.

The Republican field is a bunch of self-compromised people, I am sorry to say.

It's Obama to lose this election, I think !!
Mr. Obama is not a serial adulterer, Mr. Gingrich is.  Open and closed case on family values.

President Obama may not be all he was cracked up to be. But he has done a good job leading our nation despite inheriting a recession, two wars, and a large deficit, and facing a conservative rump that has been hell bent on obstructing every attempt to address those issues. President Obama's performance in stabilizing our economy, achieving progress in terms of health care and banking reform, taking out Al-Qaeda, and re-establishing our prestige in the world easily earns him re-election, despite his shortcomings in a number of areas.

In addition, it is clear that we cannot trust the GOP to lead. When they had power before President Obama, the GOP implemented economic policies that drove our economy into the ditch and flatlined incomes, while launching an unnecessary war in Iraq, alienating us from much of the world, and failing to capture or kill Bin Laden. In 2010, the GOP took over the House and then turned Congress into a fundamentally broken institution with a 9% approval rating. And now the GOP has a set of complete know-nothings running for President, along with Multiple Choice Mitt Romney and serial adulterer Newt Gingrich. Each of those candidates is offering little more than warmed over versions of the failed economic policies of the past 30 years, combined with proposals to abolish Medicare.

I'd stick with the sure leadership of President Obama.

http://www.winningprogressive.org

https://www.facebook.com/pages/Winning-Progressive/195682780442236

The problem is the inate hatred for Pres Obama, a President who I must remind people approached GOP powers seeking co operation and legislation to cure what ailed our economy. From the mouth of Mitch McConnell, we will work diligently to see that Obama is a one term President" Verbatum. Now if thats politics today it will not matter whether Presidents are elected to one six or seven year term or two four year terms or one four year term. Our problem lay in the fact that those now in Washington D.C. put themselves ahead of party, party ahead of country. Without a massive infrastructure spending bill in the begining of the next Presidential cycle the chances of a real economic recovery in the United States are slim and none. Without public funds being used to instantly put millions back to work, small business will not grow to support a new workforce. Without small business growth we are doomed. Big business has little plans to hire in the millions, quite the contrary they seek people who are willing to retire early with limited benefits or one time payouts. In closing let me say, if the United States approached the Fed IMF & world bank with a proposal to increase taxes at least back to Clinton era rates, impose a stock& commodoities trading fee tax and raise our  federal gas tax. We could borrow that money at less than 1% put millions back to work,and never approach 128% of debt to GDP ratio we experienced after WWII. Which we did survive and thrive  creating our middle class

Not sure I understand this.  The recent boom/bust was to much money ending up in housing.  Housing prices rising artificially, areas overbuilt, houses to big, people flipping houses, taking out second mortgages on artificially high valuations etc etc.  This was momentum investing. This grew the construction industry (and the realtor, and mortgage broker, and derivative) way past the point it should have in the time frame.   You want to do it all over again now?

You are right again Mr. Friedman. But you ignored the job creation of the construction industry. Particularly home building. Money spent to bring home owners from underwater could ignite the housing market that led us out of every recession except the great one. Then your idea of hubs would work. But only if we get from underwater in housing.
To get the funding for this, we need either new rules for the senate or a great Democratic victory that gives them a super majority. The republican party as ruled by the extremists must go.

I don't think you got Friedman's point. This economic problem can be resolved--if Obama would just propose a Grand Plan, one that would broadly appeal to--and capture the imagination and support of--all the people. Instead of playing small ball.

It is true that our economic problem has a complex history, but Obama can be--and needs to be--the Leader, and begin the movement towards the solution. The journey of a thousand miles begins with the first step.

It's not just first "100 days" or the next. We have just hyped up the public to expect that to measure any President's success by. Highly unfair in this intricate global economy.

Economic problems, particularly with a long complex history, cannot all be resolved after the weekend. Too simplistic a hope to keep tantalizing us with.

Can you be at least realistic???

For Kevin Rothstein , the GOP is split between tea party know nothings and a few sensible Senators. Any third party in 2012 election insures Obama re-election. Lets hope you help someone the likes of Paul Rand, perhaps you think The Donald Trump mouth has the answers. The GOP field is so weak, Donald Trump such an egotist. you wish for a third party? Two parties can't agree on the color the bathroom should be painted so three will make it right? You logic escapes me, the problem is not the parties, it is the dumbing down of our population who have been conned for years with religious conservatives playing peoples religious beliefs for votes. That is the problem, they forget to seperate church and state. If it were up to evangelical christians that is exactly what this country would be a evangelical christian country. Scary thought, if it does not scare you, seek help.
